entry.et: Middle English finisshen, from Anglo-French finiss-, stem of finir, from Latin finire, from finis

def.dt: :to come to an end :terminate
:end 1b
:to come to the end of a course, task, or undertaking
:to end relations used with with decided to finish with him for good
:to end a competition in a specified manner or position finished third in the race
:to bring to an end :terminate finished the speech and sat down
:to use or dispose of entirely her sandwich finished the loaf
:to bring to completion or issue hope to finish their new home before winter
:to provide with a finish
:to put a final coat or surface on finish a table with varnish
:to defeat or ruin utterly and finally the scandal finished his career
:to bring about the death of
:something that completes or perfects: as
:the fine or decorative work required for a building or one of its parts
:a finishing material used in painting
:the final treatment or coating of a surface
:the taste in the mouth after swallowing a beverage (as wine)
:final stage :end
:the cause of one's ruin
:the result or product of a finishing process a glossy finish
:the quality or state of being perfected
:a line marking the end of a racecourse
:a finish in which the winner comes from behind at the end
:a race or finish in which contestants are so close that a photograph of them as they cross the finish line has to be examined to determine the winner
:a close contest
